Senators ask nominees about Trump’s potential defiance of court orders A Senate confirmation hearing on Wednesday for three top Justice Department lawyers was dominated by concerns from lawmakers who asked when, if ever, a president could defy a court order. Democrats and Republican Sen. John Neely Kennedy (Louisiana) made clear they think the answer should be never. But Aaron Reitz, President Donald Trump’s nominee to lead the department’s Office of Legal Policy, was equivocal on the matter. D. John Sauer, the president’s pick to serve as the government’s top advocate at the Supreme Court, was more definitive. The question was urgent, Democratic lawmakers said, as judges throughout the country have forcefully pushed back on Trump’s efforts to shrink the federal workforce, halt government spending and dismantle federal agencies. Some Trump administration officials, including Vice President JD Vance, have publicly questioned the authority of judges in response to recent rulings against some of the president’s executive orders. The administration on Wednesday was appealing a looming court deadline to pay hundreds of millions in foreign assistance funds that have remained in limbo despite a judge’s previous order. “There is no hard and fast rule in all instances in which a litigant must comply with all or some or various parts of a judicial decision,” Reitz, who is currently chief of staff to Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), told lawmakers at the hearing. “It is so fact-, law- and case-specific that one cannot speak generally.” Sauer, who has represented Trump in his previous criminal cases, said, “Generally, if there’s a direct court order that binds a federal or state official, they should follow it.” As to whether Trump would defy a direct order, he said that having represented Trump for nearly two years, “I just think that’s not a plausible scenario.” In response to those answers, Kennedy offered a forceful directive to the president’s nominees: “Don’t ever, ever take the position that you’re not going to follow the order of a federal court — ever. Now, you can disagree with it within the bounds of legal ethics. You can criticize it. You can appeal it or you can resign,” he said. He separately noted his frustration with what he called efforts to undermine the legitimacy of the judiciary during the Biden administration. The committee also heard Wednesday from Harmeet K. Dhillon, a California lawyer and Republican National Committee member who is nominated to lead the department’s civil rights division. She, too, worked as one of Trump’s private attorneys. Sauer, who is nominated to serve as solicitor general, has already scored one landmark victory for Trump before the Supreme Court, winning a broad expansion of presidential immunity in Trump’s election interference case. Sen. Peter Welch (D-Vermont) invoked that court decision Wednesday when he raised concerns about the power of Congress to restrain the president’s authority, citing what he called “a profoundly new set of expectations and boundaries about what the executive power is now.” If confirmed by the Senate, Sauer would play a critical role shaping the administration’s legal strategy as it responds to a flood of litigation over Trump’s aggressive moves. Sauer, a Rhodes scholar and graduate of Harvard Law School, was a law clerk to conservative justice Antonin Scalia and another leading conservative, J. Michael Luttig, a former appeals court judge. He spent five years as a federal prosecutor before becoming the solicitor general of Missouri when the state attorney general’s office was led by Josh Hawley and then Eric Schmitt — both of whom are now Republican U.S. senators from the state. They had high praise for Sauer when they introduced him to the committee Wednesday. After he left the state attorney general’s office, he opened a small law practice instead of joining a big firm. “I don’t think John wanted to be in a position where he couldn’t do work that interested him because it conflicted with the business of the firm,” said John Demers, who worked alongside Sauer as a co-clerk to Scalia and led the Justice Department’s national security division in the first Trump administration. “He took cases he believed in, and he wanted to have the freedom to do them.” In addition to defending Trump personally, Sauer joined unsuccessful efforts to try to overturn the 2020 presidential election results and has a long track record of advocating for conservative causes. He has defended restrictions on transgender athletes in Arizona and efforts to limit access to abortion in Missouri. Sauer also helped lead litigation accusing the Biden administration of collaborating with social media platforms to censor conservative voices online. Last year, Sauer donated hundreds of thousands of dollars to Missouri Right to Life’s political action committee as it opposed a ballot measure to protect abortion rights in the state, according to Missouri campaign finance records reviewed by The Washington Post. In court, he often tangled with attorney Chuck Hatfield, who represented Planned Parenthood in Missouri in its efforts to retain funding and renew a license to operate a surgical abortion center. Hatfield called Sauer fast-talking, hardworking and incredibly bright. He also said Sauer is “not the kind of lawyer who is going to try to dissuade his client from a position that he thinks might be a stretch or inconsistent with current law.” “John is not likely to be a roadblock to policy positions his clients want to take,” said Hatfield, who earlier spent a decade working in the state attorney general’s office. “He’s more likely to be an advocate in favor of those positions — and a very good, a very smart one.” In Scalia’s chambers, Sauer stood out for his wide-ranging knowledge, outstanding memory, and ability to talk about everything from pop culture to theology and philosophy. “He’s never offensive, but he loves to argue,” Demers said of Sauer’s style. “He argues on the substance; it’s not an argument about who can raise their voice louder.” In the days before Trump’s return to the White House, Sauer continued to represent him at the Supreme Court. He tried unsuccessfully to delay Trump’s sentencing in New York for his hush money conviction and filed an unusual brief seeking an opportunity for Trump to negotiate a deal to prevent TikTok, the video-sharing app, from going dark. “President Trump alone possesses the consummate dealmaking expertise, the electoral mandate, and the political will to negotiate a resolution to save the platform while addressing the national security concerns expressed by the Government,” Sauer wrote. The brief was criticized by the Wall Street Journal editorial page and others for not staking out a legal position and suggesting that there could be more than one president at a time. Sauer’s most high-profile role came last year, when he asked the Supreme Court to rule that Trump — accused in D.C. federal court of trying to overturn Joe Biden’s 2020 election victory — should be broadly protected from prosecution for his official actions while in the White House. In response to a hypothetical question from Justice Sonia Sotomayor, Sauer suggested that it could be an official action, and therefore immune, if a president ordered the military to assassinate a political rival. The high court’s conservative supermajority ruled in favor of Trump, saying that a president’s official actions could not be prosecuted, though his private conduct could be. Luttig, who has become an outspoken Trump critic, said his former law clerk is intellectually honest and has great integrity. While Luttig disagreed with the court’s immunity ruling, he said Sauer made the only possible argument that could save Trump from criminal prosecution. “A man who can convince the Supreme Court that the Constitution affords the President of the United States absolute immunity can convince the Supreme Court the Constitution means anything he wants,” Luttig said. “That the Supreme Court bought the fallacious argument hook, line and sinker was not to Mr. Sauer’s discredit. It was to the Supreme Court’s discredit.” All three nominees seemed to have the support they would need from Republicans to advance to the full Senate. As head of the Justice Department’s civil rights division, Dhillon would oversee an office whose work traditionally has included investigating police misconduct, enforcing voting rights and filing cases over alleged civil rights violations. If confirmed, she would be the first Sikh American to hold the position. Dhillon has previously garnered attention for her legal work targeting social media companies, challenging corporate diversity policies, and suing over California’s pandemic restrictions. Reitz, a Marine Corps veteran who previously worked for Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton (R), would oversee a Justice Department office tasked with advising the attorney general on policy and assisting in the selection of nominees for the federal bench. Democrats repeatedly confronted him Wednesday with his past posts on the social media site X, many of which have been deleted. One post from March 2020 responded to a ruling from U.S. District Judge Lee Yeakel temporarily blocking Texas from closing an abortion clinic during the covid pandemic. “Judge Yeakal has made his decision. Now let him enforce it,” Reitz wrote, echoing an apocryphal quote attributed to Andrew Jackson in response to a much earlier court ruling. He was asked at multiple points during Wednesday’s hearing to commit to the concept that even the president should be bound by adverse court rulings. Reitz repeatedly resisted giving a firm answer. “My position reflects a fairly mainstream view within right-of-center jurisprudential circles, which is simply to suggest that various Supreme Court or Court of Appeals decisions are more limited in scope than maybe our friends who share a different jurisprudential view of Supreme Court holdings would suggest,” he said. Sen. Cory Booker (D-New Jersey) pushed back. “You’re not giving me great confidence by not stating unequivocally that we are a nation that respects the separation of powers, the role of the courts and … the traditions of the country,” he said. Razzan Nakhlawi contributed to this report.
